text: What is the valid most compressed format possible of the IPv6 address 2001:0DB8:0000:AB00:0000:0000:0000:1234?
explanation: IPv6 compression involves removing leading zeros in each hextet and replacing the longest single contiguous sequence of zero hextets with '::'. For 2001:0DB8:0000:AB00:0000:0000:0000:1234, we drop leading zeros and compress the final four zero blocks into '::'. Note that '::' can only be used once.

text: What is the prefix associated with the IPv6 address 2001:DB8:D15:EA:CC44::1/64?
explanation: A /64 prefix indicates that the first 64 bits (the first four hextets) represent the network. For 2001:DB8:D15:EA:CC44::1, the first four hextets are 2001:DB8:D15:EA, making the network prefix 2001:DB8:D15:EA::/64.

text: What type of address is automatically assigned to an interface when IPv6 is enabled on that interface?
explanation: Enabling IPv6 on an interface triggers the automatic generation of a link-local address (prefix FE80::/10). These are required for local network communication like Neighbor Discovery Protocol (NDP) and are not routable.

text: Which IPv6 network prefix is only intended for local links and can not be routed?
explanation: FE80::/10 is reserved for link-local addresses. These are non-routable and exist only within a single local segment or broadcast domain.

text: What is the purpose of the command ping ::1?

options.text: It tests the internal configuration of an IPv6 host.
It tests the broadcast capability of all hosts on the subnet.
It tests the multicast connectivity to all hosts on the subnet.
It tests the reachability of the default gateway for the network.

explanation: The address ::1 is the IPv6 loopback address (equivalent to 127.0.0.1 in IPv4). Pinging it verifies that the host's own TCP/IP stack is properly installed and functioning.

text: What is the interface ID of the IPv6 address 2001:DB8::1000:A9CD:47FF:FE57:FE94/64?
explanation: In a /64 address, the last 64 bits (the last four hextets) are the interface ID. Expanding the address shows the last four hextets are A9CD:47FF:FE57:FE94. Note that '1000' is part of the fourth hextet and thus the network portion in this specific compressed string.

text: What is the network address for the IPv6 address 2001:DB8:AA04:B5::1/64?
explanation: Under a /64 prefix, the first four hextets constitute the network. For 2001:DB8:AA04:B5::1/64, those hextets are 2001:DB8:AA04:B5, making the network address 2001:DB8:AA04:B5::/64.

text: Which address type is not supported in IPv6?
explanation: IPv6 does not use broadcast. Instead, it uses multicast for 'one-to-many' and anycast for 'one-to-nearest' delivery, which is more efficient and reduces network noise.

text: What is indicated by a successful ping to the ::1 IPv6 address?

options.text: The default gateway address is correctly configured.
All hosts on the local link are available.
The link-local address is correctly configured.
IP is properly installed on the host.

explanation: Pinging the loopback address (::1) is an internal test. It confirms that the IPv6 protocol stack is active and operational on the local machine without testing external network hardware.

text: What is the most compressed representation of the IPv6 address 2001:0db8:0000:abcd:0000:0000:0000:0001?
explanation: Compressing 2001:0db8:0000:abcd:0000:0000:0000:0001: 1) Drop leading zeros (db8, 0, abcd, 0, 0, 0, 1). 2) Use '::' for the longest sequence of zeros. This yields 2001:db8:0:abcd::1.

text: What is the minimum configuration for a router interface that is enabled for IPv6?

options.text: To have a link-local IPv6 address
To have both an IPv4 and an IPv6 address
To have a self-generated loopback address
To have both a link-local and a global unicast IPv6 address

explanation: At a minimum, an IPv6-enabled interface must have a link-local address. This allows for basic local communication and functions like router advertisements even without a global address.

text: At a minimum, which address is required on IPv6-enabled interfaces?
explanation: Every IPv6 interface requires a link-local address (FE80::/10). It is essential for link-layer operations and neighbor discovery protocols.

text: What are three parts of an IPv6 global unicast address? (Choose three.)

options.text: An interface ID that is used to identify the local network for a particular host
A global routing prefix provided by an ISP
A subnet ID used to identify networks inside the local site
A global routing prefix provided by a local administrator
An interface ID used to identify the local host on the network

explanation: The global unicast address structure consists of: 1) Global Routing Prefix (from ISP), 2) Subnet ID (internal organization), and 3) Interface ID (specific host).

text: Given a /48 prefix, how many bits are available to create /64 subnetworks?
explanation: The difference between a /48 prefix and the standard /64 subnet boundary is 16 bits (64 - 48 = 16), allowing for 65,536 unique subnets.

text: Which type of IPv6 address is not routable and used only for communication on a single subnet?
explanation: Link-local addresses (FE80::/10) are used specifically for communication within a local subnet. Routers do not forward these addresses to other networks.
